newsitem.title: FRANCE: Eramet board postpones decision, chairman stays on.
newsitem.headline: Eramet board postpones decision, chairman stays on.

text.p: French nickel producer Eramet said on Tuesday its board will conduct an in-depth study of a proposal by state-controlled ERAP to change the legal status of the company.
"The board reviewed a proposal put forward by ERAP to turn Eramet into a company with a supervisory and a management board," Eramet said in a statement.
"The board expressed its interest in the project and decided to conduct an in-depth study on the issue," it said.
Asked if this meant Eramet's management team would stay on, a company spokesman told Reuters "Yes indeed".
The spokesman could not say how long the review might take, suggesting it could be weeks or months before a decision was taken.
The board confirmed Eramet was ready "if needed" to lend support to plans for a (nickel) project in the north of New Caledonia, the statement said.
But the support must be "compatible" with Eramet's long-term interest and development plans in the French territory.
The French government said earlier on Tuesday that it had no intention of stripping Eramet's mining assets in New Caledonia.
Shares in Eramet hit a year low of 247 francs on Tuesday before rebounding after the government's statement. Eramet was up 14 francs at 280 at 1339 GMT.
Its shares had taken a beating on investors' concerns that the French state may force it to sell part of its mining assets in New Caledonia for political reasons.
The French government is said to be supporting a rival project in the north of the country spearheaded by local interests and Canadian group Falconbridge.
Investors also feared a change in the group's legal status might herald the ouster of chairman Yves Rambaud, who opposes plans to curb Eramet's expansion strategy in New Caledonia.
